examples.title: Simple Bar
examples.description: Bar charts (also known as vertical bar charts) represent data using vertical bars, with the height of each bar proportional to the value being plotted. They can be used to plot both nominal and ordinal data, and are simple to interpret. They work best where the number of data points is limited.
examples.name: simple-bar

examples.title: Grouped Bar
examples.description: Grouped Bar charts (also known as clustered bar charts) present multiple series with the bars grouped by category, to allow for easier comparisons across different series.
examples.name: grouped-bar

examples.title: Stacked Bar
examples.description: Stacked Bar charts allow part-to-whole comparisons, with series stacked on top of each other in the vertical bars.
examples.name: stacked-bar

examples.title: Simple Horizontal Bar
examples.description: Horizontal Bar charts represent data using horizontal bars, with the length of each bar proportional to the value being plotted. They are useful for categorical data, and are simple to interpret. They work best where the number of data points is limited.
examples.name: simple-horizontal-bar

examples.title: Grouped Horizontal Bar
examples.description: Grouped Horizontal Bar charts (also known as clustered bar charts) show multiple series with the bars grouped by category, to allow for easier comparisons across different series.
examples.name: grouped-horizontal-bar

examples.title: Stacked Horizontal Bar
examples.description: Stacked Horizontal Bar charts allow part-to-whole comparisons, with series stacked from left to right in the horizontal bars. They make it easy to compare combined bar lengths.
examples.name: stacked-horizontal-bar

examples.title: Simple Line
examples.description: Line charts represent each series as a separate line. They are useful to show change or trends over time, and are able to better present more data points than bar charts.
examples.name: simple-line

examples.title: Line With Gaps
examples.description: When data is missing in some line series compared to others, these gaps in the data are reflected in the lines.
examples.name: line-with-gaps

examples.title: Multiple Line Series
examples.description: Line charts represent each series as a separate line. They are useful to show change or trends over time, and are able to better present more data points than bar charts.
examples.name: multiple-line-series

examples.title: Line Series With Time Axis
examples.description: Line charts represent each series as a separate line. They are useful to show change or trends over time, and are able to better present more data points than bar charts.
examples.name: line-legend-pagination

examples.title: Multiple Line Series With Large Data
examples.description: When data is missing in some line series compared to others, these gaps in the data are reflected in the lines.
examples.name: multiple-line-series-large-data

examples.title: Line Series With Labels
examples.description: Line charts represent each series as a separate line. They are useful to show change or trends over time, and are able to better present more data points than bar charts.
examples.name: line-with-labels

examples.title: Simple Area
examples.description: Area charts plot series using a line with the area below the line filled. They are useful to show changes over time, and are easy to interpret.
examples.name: simple-area

examples.title: Stacked Area
examples.description: Stacked area charts plot multiple area series stacked on top of each other, showing how part-to-whole relationships change over time.
examples.name: stacked-area

examples.title: 100% Stacked Area
examples.description: 100% stacked area charts show the relative percentage of multiple series in stacked areas, where the cumulative area always totals to 100%.
examples.name: 100--stacked-area

examples.title: Area With Negative Values
examples.description: Area charts can also be used with negative values, with the area between the line and the axis being filled.
examples.name: area-with-negative-values

examples.title: Simple Scatter
examples.description: Scatter charts (also known as scatter plots or XY charts) show the relationship between two variables, placing one variable on each axis, and can be useful for demonstrating any correlation between the variables.
examples.name: simple-scatter

examples.title: Simple Bubble
examples.description: Bubble charts are a specialised type of scatter charts that can represent a third variable through the size of each marker (or bubble).
examples.name: simple-bubble

examples.title: Multiple Bubble Series
examples.description: The axes of scatter and bubble charts can be extended to plot positive and negative values.
examples.name: multiple-bubble-series

examples.title: Bubble With Negative Values
examples.description: The axes of scatter and bubble charts can be extended to plot positive and negative values.
examples.name: bubble-with-negative-values

examples.title: Bubble With Categories
examples.description: The axes of scatter and bubble charts can show categories in addition to values.
examples.name: bubble-with-categories

examples.title: Bubble With Labels
examples.description: The axes of scatter and bubble charts can show categories in addition to values.
examples.name: bubble-with-labels

examples.title: Simple Pie
examples.description: Pie charts are used to express a part-to-whole relationship, where all the slices combine to represent 100%. They work best for a small number of categories.
examples.name: simple-pie

examples.title: Pie With Variable Radius
examples.description: Pie sectors radius can be encoded by an additional numeric scale.
examples.name: pie-with-variable-radius

examples.title: Pie In A Doughnut
examples.description: There can be multiple levels of Pie/Doughnut charts. It can be used when comparing shares for different periods.
examples.name: pie-in-a-doughnut

examples.title: Simple Doughnut
examples.description: Doughnut charts are similar to pie charts, being used to express a part-to-whole relationship, but allow for multiple series to be shown on the same chart for comparison.
examples.name: simple-doughnut

examples.title: Simple Combination
examples.description: A combination chart combines two or more series types allowing for flexible data visualisations. They are ideal for making visual comparisons of different sets of data in a single chart.
examples.name: combination-of-different-series-types

examples.title: Simple Histogram
examples.description: Histograms show your data grouped into bins, revealing underlying trends. A standard histogram plots the population size of each bin against the y-axis. Here we show the distribution of car engine sizes, using the engine-size field from the available data.
examples.name: simple-histogram

examples.title: Histogram With Specified Bins
examples.description: Rather than using the automatically generated fixed-width bins, it is possible to explicitly specify bins. In this case the bins can be different widths. In the example below the data is split into light, medium, and heavy vehicles, and we also demonstrate custom tooltips to give names to these categories.
examples.name: histogram-with-specified-bins

examples.title: XY Histogram With Mean Aggregation
examples.description: Here we bin the data by car engine size, but plot the average highway MPG in the y-axis, revealing the relationship between these two fields. We also plot the same data as a scatter series to illustrate the aggregation.
examples.name: xy-histogram-with-mean-aggregation

examples.title: Simple Heatmap
examples.description: A Heatmap Series is using the colour-coding to represent numeric values in a form of a colourful matrix.
examples.name: simple-heatmap

examples.title: Calendar Heatmap
examples.description: A Heatmap Series is using the colour-coding to represent numeric values in a form of a colourful matrix.
examples.name: calendar-heatmap

examples.title: Simple Range Bar
examples.description: Range Bar charts (also known as vertical range bar charts) represent data using vertical bars, with the height of each bar proportional to the range value being plotted. They work best where the number of data points is limited.
examples.name: simple-range-bar

examples.title: Multiple Range Bars
examples.description: Range Bar charts (also known as vertical range bar charts) represent data using vertical bars, with the height of each bar proportional to the range value being plotted. They work best where the number of data points is limited.
examples.name: multiple-range-bars

examples.title: Horizontal Range Bar
examples.description: Horizontal Bar charts represent data using horizontal bars, with the length of each bar proportional to the range value being plotted. They work best where the number of data points is limited.
examples.name: horizontal-range-bar

examples.title: Multiple Horizontal Range Bar
examples.description: Horizontal Bar charts represent data using horizontal bars, with the length of each bar proportional to the range value being plotted. They work best where the number of data points is limited.
examples.name: multiple-horizontal-range-bars

examples.title: Simple Range Area
examples.description: A Range Area Series shows an area between high and low data values. It's used to monitor data consistency or variability.
examples.name: simple-range-area

examples.title: Range Area Missing Data
examples.description: A Range Area Series shows an area between high and low data values. It's used to monitor data consistency or variability.
examples.name: range-area-missing-data

examples.title: Multiple Range Areas
examples.description: A Range Area Series shows an area between high and low data values. It's used to monitor data consistency or variability.
examples.name: multiple-range-areas

examples.title: Simple Box Plot
examples.description: A Box Plot Series, also known as a Box-and-Whisker Plot, visually summarises a dataset's distribution through its median and quartiles.
examples.name: simple-box-plot

examples.title: Horizontal Box Plot
examples.description: A Box Plot Series, also known as a Box-and-Whisker Plot, visually summarises a dataset's distribution through its median and quartiles.
examples.name: horizontal-box-plot

examples.title: Box Plot Outliers
examples.description: A Box Plot Series, also known as a Box-and-Whisker Plot, visually summarises a dataset's distribution through its median and quartiles.
examples.name: box-plot-outliers

examples.title: Simple Waterfall
examples.description: A Waterfall Series shows the cumulative effect of sequential positive or negative data values. It utilises rising and falling bars to create a cascading waterfall effect.
examples.name: simple-waterfall

examples.title: Horizontal Waterfall
examples.description: A Waterfall Series shows the cumulative effect of sequential positive or negative data values. It utilises rising and falling bars to create a cascading waterfall effect.
examples.name: horizontal-waterfall

examples.title: Customised Waterfall
examples.description: A Waterfall Series shows the cumulative effect of sequential positive or negative data values. It utilises rising and falling bars to create a cascading waterfall effect.
examples.name: customised-waterfall

examples.title: Simple Radar Line
examples.description: A Radar Line Series is typically used to contrast different datasets across shared categories for easy visual comparison.
examples.name: simple-radar-line

examples.title: Radar With Markers
examples.description: A Radar Line Series is typically used to contrast different datasets across shared categories for easy visual comparison.
examples.name: radar-with-markers

examples.title: Simple Radar Area
examples.description: A Radar Area Series shows the magnitude of various datasets within shared categories, making it easier to gauge area-based trends.
examples.name: simple-radar-area

examples.title: Simple Nightingale
examples.description: A Nightingale Series represents data as radial segments, with one segment per category value. It can simplify the comparison of datasets across multiple categories, providing a concise depiction of data trends.
examples.name: simple-nightingale

examples.title: Simple Radial Column
examples.description: A Radial Column Series visualises data through rectangular columns arranged along a polar axis.
examples.name: simple-radial-column

examples.title: Stacked Radial Bar
examples.description: A Radial Bar Series visualises data through rectangular bars arranged along a polar axis.
examples.name: stacked-radial-bar

examples.title: Market Index Treemap
examples.description: A treemap of a snapshot of the S&P 500 stock market index.
examples.name: market-index-treemap
